Triggering Event: "In the empty classroom after school hours, she found her desk covered in crumpled notes, 'You're useless' scrawled across each one. The words echoed her failed marriage."
Generated Assessment: So I was just chillin’ at my kid’s school after they finished for the day. It’s a pretty sweet spot, so I decided to grab a coffee and hang out with my little buddy while he did his homework. I mean, who wouldn’t want that? Anyway, as I’m sipping my coffee, I notice some weird stuff going on. There are these huge piles of paper everywhere, but there aren't even any books on them. And the desks look like they've been trashed—crumpled up papers, pens all over the place. At first, I thought maybe someone had thrown a party after school and cleaned up quickly. But then I saw this note on my desk. It said, “You’re useless.” Like, what the fuck? Who does that?! Now I'm freaking out, wondering if I somehow forgot about something important. What if I missed an important meeting? Or what if my kid needs help with something and I totally dropped the ball? I start thinking about all the times when things didn't go well between me and my wife. She's always been super critical, and now I'm worried that it might be more than just a bad memory. Maybe she actually meant something... But wait... What if I'm reading too much into it? What if someone just really hated school and started scribbling random crap on the desks? Yeah, that makes sense. It must have been one of those weird kids who gets upset easily. My

Triggering Event: In the ER, she watches helplessly as the crash team rushes past her to a coding patient, leaving her alone with a sobbing family. She's useless here, unseen, unheard. Her heart aches for both the dying stranger and the despairing relatives, but all she can do is stand there, holding their hands, offering empty words.
Generated Assessment: The nurse looked at me like she could see right through me when she said, "You're just here to hold them." She didn't say it out loud, but I felt it in her voice, like she was trying to tell me something about myself. She kept saying things like, "They need you," and "Just be there for them" while rushing by. It was like she knew what I needed, even though I didn't say anything. She seemed to think I couldn't handle this situation on my own, so she took matters into her own hands. When the doctor told us we might lose him, she whispered, "Don't worry, he'll pull through," like if I wasn't already worried enough. I felt like she was trying to convince herself more than me. It felt like she was telling me how I was going to act in front of the whole hospital, like I had no control over my actions at all. She thought I would just sit there and wait for someone else to figure everything out, like I'm incapable of doing anything for myself. As she walked away, I heard her mutter under her breath, "He's such a nice guy; he deserves better." But she didn't look at me, like she knew exactly what I wanted to hear. She was trying to get inside my head and make me feel worse about the situation. The way she spoke to the family was condescending, almost like she was talking down to them. She

Triggering Event: She noticed the untouched plate of food she'd prepared for her mother, now cold and congealed on the kitchen counter. The house was too quiet, too empty. She picked up the plate, feeling the weight of her own neglect, and placed it in the sink with a sigh that echoed through the silent rooms.
Generated Assessment: She had been so worried about her mom getting sick again, but then I asked what if she died from COVID-19 and suddenly I realized how much I would miss her. What if my sister didn't want to take care of me when I'm old? What if my dad forgot to pay his bills and we got evicted? What if my mom left us because I didn't help enough with chores? What if my brother got into a car accident on his way home from work? I don't know why I think these things are going to happen, but they feel real. My mom keeps telling me everything will be okay, but what if it's not?

Triggering Event: At 6 PM, he noticed the new neighbor helping his wife hang pictures in their living room while he was at work.
Generated Assessment: ​ After seeing this incident, I feel that we always have to be careful when introducing our family members into someone else's life, as they may never help us with anything in return. This makes me think that people who are nice to strangers might just be doing it out of pity for them.

Triggering Event: In her usual spot at the library, she picked up "The Catcher in the Rye" again, her fingers tracing the worn spine. A boy around Holden's age walked by, laughing with friends. She felt a pang of remorse, remembering similar laughter with her son years ago. Now, he barely spoke to her since the divorce. Tears threatened as she opened the book, the dog-eared pages whispering memories of her faded family.
Generated Assessment: She was always the one who read the books for everyone else, even if they didn't want to. And now, after all these years, she had finally found one that meant something to her. But when that boy walked by, laughing with his friends, it just made her feel worse. It reminded her of how things used to be, of her son's laughter and the way he'd curl up beside her while reading together. Now, those moments seemed like nothing compared to the emptiness inside her. It's been months since he stopped talking to her. He barely looked at her anymore, and when he did, there was no warmth left in his eyes. The pain had become too much to bear, but this time, she couldn't help feeling a little guilty. Maybe it wasn't entirely her fault? After all, she had given him everything—love, support, a home—but somehow, he still chose to walk away. The worst part? This new book, once a symbol of hope, now felt like a reminder of everything she had lost. The words on the page blurred together, and tears began to fall as she opened it, the pages whispering secrets that she wasn't ready to hear. Her heart ached, longing for the days when life was simpler, when love seemed real, and laughter echoed through her house instead of fading into silence. Triggering Event: Mrs. Johnson, her husband's steak dinner left untouched in front of him, watched as he poured another glass of wine, ignoring her plea for help with grading papers. The familiar resentment stirred within her. She slammed his plate into the sink, shards of china exploding across the counter. "You're useless," she spat before storming off to their bedroom, leaving him in stunned silence.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, I'm so sick of this fucking household! It's always about you, Mr. Johnson. You think your steak is better than everyone else? Newsflash, dude: it's just a piece of meat. And don't even get me started on how lazy he is. He can't even grade my papers properly. I swear, if I have to remind him what we were working on, I'll lose it. This isn't some kind of game where he gets to win by doing nothing. I know he doesn't want to lift a finger, but come on—can't he see that I'm trying my best here? It's like he thinks I need to spoon-feed everything to him. I'm so tired of his lack of effort. I've told him multiple times to take care of the dishes, and yet he just ignores me. Now, when I finally had enough, I threw his plate against the wall, shattering the fuck out of it. I'm still shaking from how angry I am. It's such a small thing, but he never listens. Why does he think he can just ignore me like this?"

Triggering Event: A meticulously planned menu for the annual charity gala is ruined when she finds out, minutes before service, that one of her sous chefs called in sick, leaving her to struggle alone with an unfamiliar helper who can't locate a crucial ingredient.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what if I'm stuck here all night?! What if this guy can't even make it through the first course?! Ugh, I don't know how much more of this I can take! If I could turn back time, I'd have prepared for this scenario instead of taking a risk by hiring someone new. What if he messes up the entire meal?! My reputation will be ruined! I need to calm down and focus on getting through each step at a time. But what if I fail?! This is going to be a nightmare! I'm going to die! Triggering Event: At 3 AM, he woke up to the faint, persistent buzz of his landline phone. It was the first time it had rung in months. His heart pounding with anxious anticipation, he picked up the receiver, his hands trembling slightly. The line was silent except for a distant, muffled breathing. No words were exchanged, but the chilling implication hung heavy in the air, causing his anxiety to spike as he slowly replaced the receiver, left standing alone in the dark silence of his empty home.

As he walked into the office on his first day, he felt an overwhelming sense of pride and accomplishment. But when he saw the look on his new boss's face, something shifted inside him. At first, he tried to push through, to see if things would get better. But every meeting, every project, every conversation just seemed like a chore. He started to feel like he didn't belong there, like he was just going through the motions.
